intro: Amphilophium paraguariense, commonly known as the Paraguayan starflower, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Paraguay and Brazil. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its showy, star-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, thriving in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and often have a velvety texture, while its flowers bloom in clusters, adding ornamental value to its habitat. Despite its beauty, it is not widely cultivated, and its ecological role remains under-researched.
